text: You receive a text message saying your package delivery failed and you need to pay a small fee to reschedule.
explanation: Delivery scams use fake tracking numbers to steal payment information. Contact the courier directly.

text: Your password manager suggests generating a strong password when creating a new account.
explanation: Password managers are designed to create and store strong, unique passwords securely.

text: An email claims your streaming subscription will be cancelled unless you update payment details immediately.
explanation: Urgency tactics about subscription cancellation are common phishing methods. Log in directly to verify.

text: Your smartphone asks for your fingerprint to unlock a banking app you just opened.
explanation: Biometric authentication is a standard security feature for sensitive apps.

text: A website displays a banner warning that your internet connection is not private.
explanation: Browsers warn users about unsecured connections to protect privacy and data.

text: You get a call from someone claiming to be from the IRS threatening immediate arrest for unpaid taxes.
explanation: Tax authorities don't make threatening calls or demand immediate payment. They communicate by mail.

text: Your email client marks an incoming message as spam and moves it to the spam folder.
explanation: Email filters automatically detecting and quarantining spam is normal security behavior.

text: A social media message says you can make $500 a day working from home with no experience required.
explanation: Get-rich-quick schemes and unrealistic income promises are classic scam tactics.

text: Your router's admin panel requires you to change the default password on first setup.
explanation: Changing default passwords is essential for network security and is standard practice.

text: An email from your electric company includes a PDF attachment for your monthly bill.
explanation: Be cautious of unexpected attachments, even from apparent utility companies. Verify through official channels.

text: Your web browser asks if you want to save a password after successful login.
explanation: Modern browsers offer password saving as a convenience and security feature.

text: A pop-up claims you're the 1,000,000th visitor and have won a smartphone.
explanation: Visitor count prize claims are fake and designed to collect personal information.

text: Your company's IT department emails all employees about a mandatory security training session.
explanation: Regular security training is standard practice, but verify through official company channels.

text: A text message says your credit card has been blocked and provides a number to call immediately.
explanation: Financial institutions don't typically notify via text about blocked cards. Call the official number.

text: Your operating system prompts you to install a critical security update.
explanation: Operating system security updates are legitimate and important for system protection.

text: An email offers to sell you a college degree with no coursework required.
explanation: Diploma mills offering degrees without work are scams and provide worthless credentials.

text: Your banking app sends a push notification about a transaction you just made.
explanation: Real-time transaction notifications are legitimate security features from banks.

text: A website asks you to enable two-factor authentication for your account.
explanation: Two-factor authentication is a recommended security practice for account protection.

text: You receive a message saying your social media account has been compromised and to click a link to secure it.
explanation: Phishing messages use security fears to trick users. Log in directly to the platform instead.

text: Your firewall software blocks a suspicious incoming connection and notifies you.
explanation: Firewall alerts about blocked connections are normal security notifications.

text: An email claims you've inherited money from a distant relative in another country.
explanation: Inheritance scams prey on greed and use fake legal documents to seem legitimate.

text: Your smartphone requires a passcode after being idle for 10 minutes.
explanation: Auto-lock features are standard security measures to protect device access.

text: A website certificate warning appears when visiting a financial institution's website.
explanation: Certificate warnings on financial sites indicate potential security risks. Don't proceed.

text: Your email provider offers to encrypt your emails for enhanced privacy.
explanation: Email encryption is a legitimate security feature offered by many providers.

text: A message claims you need to verify your identity to receive a government stimulus payment.
explanation: Government payment scams use official-sounding language to steal personal information.

text: Your VPN application asks for permission to create a secure connection.
explanation: VPN software legitimately needs permission to establish secure network connections.

text: An email says your online shopping account will be suspended unless you confirm your address.
explanation: Account suspension threats are common phishing tactics. Log in directly to verify.

text: Your credit card company sends a text asking you to confirm a large purchase you just made.
explanation: Fraud alerts for unusual purchases are legitimate security measures from card companies.

text: A website offers to check if your email has been involved in any data breaches.
explanation: Legitimate breach checking services help users identify compromised accounts.

text: You receive a call offering to lower your interest rates if you provide your credit card information.
explanation: Cold calls requesting financial information are scams. Legitimate offers don't require immediate disclosure.

text: Your antivirus software quarantines a file you downloaded and explains why it's dangerous.
explanation: Antivirus quarantine actions with explanations are normal security functions.

text: An email claims your email account storage is full and you need to click a link to upgrade.
explanation: Storage upgrade phishing emails trick users into providing login credentials.

text: Your mobile carrier sends a text about suspicious activity on your account and provides a customer service number.
explanation: Carriers do send security alerts, but always verify the number independently.

text: A website asks you to complete a CAPTCHA to prove you're not a robot.
explanation: CAPTCHA systems are legitimate tools used to prevent automated attacks.

text: You get an email offering to share confidential information about a celebrity for a fee.
explanation: Celebrity gossip scams exploit curiosity and often lead to payment fraud.

text: Your computer's built-in security software scans downloaded files before opening them.
explanation: Automatic file scanning is a standard security feature in modern operating systems.

text: A message says you've won a lottery you never entered and need to pay taxes upfront.
explanation: Lottery scams require upfront payments for prizes that don't exist.

text: Your workplace requires you to use a badge to access the building.
explanation: Physical access controls using badges are standard security measures in workplaces.

text: An email attachment scanner warns you about a potentially malicious file.
explanation: Email security scanners protecting against malicious attachments are legitimate tools.

text: You receive a message claiming to be from law enforcement asking for personal information.
explanation: Law enforcement doesn't typically request personal information via email or text.

text: Your cloud storage service asks you to verify your identity after unusual login activity.
explanation: Identity verification after suspicious activity is a standard security practice.

text: A website offers to sell you prescription medications without a prescription.
explanation: Illegal pharmacy sites often sell counterfeit or dangerous medications.

text: Your smart home device asks for permission to access your network.
explanation: Smart devices legitimately need network access to function properly.

text: An email claims you need to update your software license or it will expire.
explanation: Software license phishing attempts try to get users to download malware or pay fake fees.

text: Your password manager alerts you that one of your passwords was found in a data breach.
explanation: Password managers monitoring for breached passwords is a legitimate security feature.

text: A text message offers a part-time job that requires you to receive and forward packages.
explanation: Package forwarding scams use unwitting victims to launder stolen goods.

text: Your email client asks if you want to report a suspicious email as phishing.
explanation: Email clients providing phishing reporting options help improve security for all users.

text: A website promises to increase your credit score by 200 points in 30 days.
explanation: Credit repair scams make unrealistic promises and often charge fees for ineffective services.

text: Your router logs show multiple failed login attempts from unknown IP addresses.
explanation: Router security logs showing attack attempts are legitimate security information.

text: An email says your subscription is about to renew and provides a link to cancel.
explanation: Subscription scams use fake renewal notices to steal payment information.

text: Your device asks for permission before allowing an app to access your camera.
explanation: Permission requests for device hardware access are standard privacy protections.

text: A message claims you can make money by clicking on advertisements.
explanation: Paid-to-click scams rarely pay and often steal personal information instead.

text: Your security software automatically updates its virus definitions.
explanation: Automatic security updates are essential for protection against new threats.

text: You receive an email asking you to donate to a disaster relief fund immediately.
explanation: Disaster relief scams exploit charitable impulses. Verify organizations through official channels.

text: Your banking website requires you to answer security questions before accessing your account.
explanation: Security questions are legitimate additional authentication measures used by banks.

text: A pop-up claims your computer's registry is corrupted and offers a free scan.
explanation: Registry cleaner scams use fake diagnostic results to sell unnecessary software.

text: Your workplace VPN requires you to enter a token from your authenticator app.
explanation: Multi-factor authentication using authenticator apps is a standard security practice.

text: An email offers to sell you a list of people's personal information.
explanation: Personal information sales are often illegal and involve stolen data.

text: Your browser blocks a website and warns it may contain malware.
explanation: Browser malware protection warnings are legitimate security features.

text: A message claims you can get rich by buying and selling a new cryptocurrency.
explanation: Cryptocurrency investment scams promise unrealistic returns and often steal funds.

text: Your email server scans attachments for viruses before delivering them to your inbox.
explanation: Email virus scanning is a standard security feature provided by email services.

text: You receive a call claiming your computer warranty is about to expire.
explanation: Computer warranty scams try to sell fake extended warranties or gain remote access.

text: Your mobile app asks for permission to send you security-related notifications.
explanation: Apps requesting notification permissions for security alerts is normal behavior.

text: An email promises to reveal secrets about making money online for a small fee.
explanation: Get-rich-quick schemes charging for 'secret' information are scams.

text: Your device encrypts data automatically when it's stored.
explanation: Automatic data encryption is a standard security feature in modern devices.

text: A website asks you to verify your age before accessing certain content.
explanation: Age verification is a legitimate requirement for age-restricted content.

text: You get a message saying your social security number has been suspended.
explanation: Social security numbers cannot be suspended. This is a common government impersonation scam.

text: Your cloud backup service encrypts your files before uploading them.
explanation: Client-side encryption before cloud upload is a good security practice.

text: An email offers to help you get a loan with no credit check required.
explanation: No credit check loan offers often involve predatory lending or upfront fee scams.

text: Your network administrator sends an email about new security policies.
explanation: Security policy updates from IT are legitimate, but verify through official channels.

text: A message claims you can earn money by testing websites from home.
explanation: While legitimate website testing jobs exist, unsolicited offers are often scams.

text: Your device requires you to enter a PIN after multiple failed unlock attempts.

text: You receive an email saying your internet service will be disconnected for non-payment.
explanation: ISP disconnection threats are common phishing tactics. Verify through official channels.

text: Your software asks for administrator privileges to install an update.
explanation: Administrative access for software updates is often necessary and legitimate.

text: A website offers to sell you followers for your social media account.
explanation: Fake follower services violate platform terms and often steal payment information.

text: Your security system logs all access attempts to your network.

text: An email claims you need to update your voter registration information online.

text: Your app store requires you to verify your identity before making purchases.
explanation: Purchase verification is a legitimate security measure to prevent unauthorized transactions.

text: A message offers to help you recover cryptocurrency you lost in a scam.

text: Your browser warns you before downloading executable files.

text: You receive a call claiming your utility account is overdue and service will be shut off today.

text: Your email client automatically moves emails from unknown senders to a separate folder.

text: A website promises to help you get revenge on someone who wronged you.
